results.title: The Rescue
results.creator_credit: Harry Govan, BBC Film Unit and Gordon Mackay
results.brief_description: How two young climbers get into difficulties and are saved by the joint efforts of a Royal Air Force Mountain Rescue Team and other experienced climbers. Contrasts correct ways of mountain climbing with careless methods. Set in the mountains of Argyll and Inverness.

results.title: The Republic of the Philippines
results.creator_credit: Leo Guelpa Jr, Dudley Pictures and United World Films
results.brief_description: Republic of the Philippines, seen through the eyes of a young Filipino teacher. The geographical background, the native races, the landscape, cultivation of various crops, the development of industries, mineral resources, forest products and hydro-electricity, and the growth of the education and public health systems.

results.title: The Republic of South Africa: the land and its people - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Clifford J. Kamen and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Compares three ways of life in the Republic of South Africa: tribal life, white farmers and mining communities. Shows how the culture patterns of each region are influenced by the topography climate, and resources of the region.

results.title: The Report
results.creator_credit: Royal North Shore Hospital of Sydney, New South Wales. Dept. of Health, Pamela Scott, Suzy Molony and Tony Wheeler
results.brief_description: A dramatised film of a day in the life of an assistant personnel manager. An annual report is overdue and as a result of his own inefficiency, the main character allows the day’s events to finally overwhelm him. Ideal discussion promoter about how to organise commitments so as to cope effectively with the demads of work and personal life. Cinematography by Tom Cowan. Written and directed by Tony Wheeler.

results.title: The Renaissance: its beginnings in Italy
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The significance of the Renaissance in art, thought, and science is explained in terms of its contrast to the mediaeval world, its rediscovery of the ancient and its contribution to the modern. Examples of Renaissance art are taken from the work of Giotto, Michelangelo, Luca della Robbia, Andrea Pisano, Filippo Brunelleschi and Lorenzo Ghiberti. The role of the Medicis and the great Italian cities as patrons of art is discussed, and the varied achievements of Leonardo do Vinci are shown as exemplifying the spirit of the Renaissance: a vigorous interest in all aspects of man and the world, and the urge to understand them through science. These led to a new approach to art and laid the foundations of modern science.

results.title: The Renaissance & the new world
results.creator_credit: Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.) and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “The Western tradition”.
During the 15th and 16th Centuries, the Europeans were confronted by the discovery of new societies which challenged their understanding of the world and provoked a revolution in critical thinking. Prof. Eugen Weber asks,”What motivated the great explorers of the Renaissance, and how did their attitudes differ from a medieval mentality?” The New World was perceived as an earthly paradise and its people mythologised as “noble savages”. The importance of religion is explored, and how Christianity provided a rationale for slavery. Using Leonardo Da Vinci as a case study, Weber stresses the significance a new critical and comparative way of thinking, where knowledge was subject to revision on the basis of experience and observation.

results.title: The Renaissance
results.brief_description: Analyses the development, meaning and effect of the Renaissance. The church is shown as a powerful force in the Middle-Ages and combined with the system of feudalism it checked social advances. Copyright 1950 David A. Smart No other credits available.

results.title: The Removalists
results.brief_description: The story is the tragedy of a young police constable, new to the force and tongue-tied with inhibitions. Circumstances move him to murder, not only of a man, but also of his own morality. The dialogue - screenplay by David Williamson - is a unique combination of irony, cynicism, naivety and vulgar vitality, and the film explores subtle relationships. Based on the play by David Williamson. Stars John Hargreaves, Peter Cummins, Kate Fitzpatrick, Jacki Weaver and Chris Haywood.

results.title: The Remarkable school house
results.creator_credit: Isaac Kleinerman, Peter Poor and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
Shows new teaching methods in use, particularly computer applications, and discusses the changes in schools to be expected in coming decades. Reporter Walter Cronkite.

results.title: The Remarkable riderless runaway tricycle
results.creator_credit: Evergreen Productions, John Sturner and Gary Templeton
results.brief_description: A humorous fantasy about a little boy’s tricycle which is mistakenly picked up by garbage collectors and taken to the tip. However, the tricycle mysteriously takes on a personality and a will of its own, escapes from the tip and returns to its owner - but not before having aroused the suspicion of the garbage collectors and the police road patrol. Based on the book by Bruce McNillan.
